resources.string:
Here you can modify different parameters of the displayed earthquakes. Like minimum magnitude or maximum magnitude of the earthquakes. 

Please keep in mind the default values of the parameters and restrictions. Default values:
 - start date: current date and time minus 30 days
 - end date: current date and time
 - order by: time in descending order
 - radius: 500 km
 
So if you don't change anything, you'll see the last earthquakes that happened in the past 30 days in a 500 km radius, ordered from the latest to the earliest.

 PS: Did you know that there are earthquakes with a negative magnitude? Set the maximum magnitude to zero and the radius to 20 000 and see what happens.
We couldn\'t find your location. Please check that the app has permission to acces your location and restart the app.
Permission denied. We need your location to show the earthquakes.
%s date invalid. Examples of correct dates: 2000–01–01, 2018–12–31.
End date should be after start date.

This app uses information provided by the United States Geological Survey (USGS). Which means that, unfortunately, you won't be able to see all the small earthquakes that happen around the world, each day. As a rule, only the stronger earthquakes that happen outside the USA will be shown in the app. Nonetheless, the USGS database also holds information regarding earthquakes that happened decades or centuries ago. 

 To use the app, you must allow it to access your location. That's the whole point of it, right? To see the earthquakes that happen in a radius starting from the user's location. 

 This app is not officially endorsed by USGS and the developer is not responsible for the accuracy of the data. Also, this app doesn't send alerts when an earthquake has happened. Nor does it predict them - which is impossible, by the way :).
Earthquake data compiled by the U.S. Geological Survey\nVisit the USGS at https://usgs.gov
